results.title: Fabrics in motion
results.brief_description: An experimental film in which an attempt is made to focus attention on the work of the textile designer. The film consists of five miniature solo ballets, each being based on new patterns for fabrics sketched by the textile designer. No explanatory commentary on the ballet is provided - the story of each ballet is left to the imagination of the audience.

results.title: Fabrications
results.brief_description: This film explores the work of Australian and European artists (such as Tadek Butlich from Britain and Isobel Foster from Australia) in the field of fabric sculpture, embroidery, and wall hangings. Detailed observation reveals wide variety in the use of textures, colors and fabrics. The film is not narrated; an electronic score complements the images. This film is suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: Fable of he and she
results.creator_credit: Eliot Noyes and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description: An animated fable which challenges stereotyped and sexist thinking, and celebrates the joys of individual self-expression.

results.title: F.I.D.O. = Fido
results.creator_credit: Steve Sculley and Victorian College of the Arts
results.brief_description: Told from the point of view of Harry, a black labrador, F.I.D.O. follows the controversial path of the Fairfield Industrial Design Object - appropriately named F.I.D.O. The project materialises itself in real life in the form of a proposed public art structure - a 6 metre high dog with lights and a moving tail. We hear from the artists themselves, outraged residents who feel like they have been left out of the democratic process, and a supportive Darebin Council member. Regardless of the outcome and opinions expressed, two things remain - there are a lot of dogs in the City of Darebin, and the face of Fairfield is changing.

results.title: Ezra Pound: poets' poet
results.creator_credit: Harold Mantell and Films for the Humanities
results.brief_description: Uses historic photographs, early documentary footage and the poet’s own recollections to explore the life of Ezra Pound. Born in Idaho, he spent his boyhood in Philadelphia, before moving to England. Other aspects of his life covered in this film are his asociation in Paris in the 1920s with other expatriates, such as Joyce, Stein and Hemingway, and his love affair with Rapallo and Venice. Some of the moods evoked by Pound’s poetry are highlighted. Suitable for secondary level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Harold Mantell and Films for the Humanities

results.title: Ezra Jack Keats (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Cynthia Freitag, Morton Schindel and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description: This film introduces the personality and style of Ezra Jack Keats, Caldecott Medallist, author and illustrator of well-known picture books. It concludes with an iconographic film rendition of one of his books “A Letter to Amy”.

results.title: Eye of an artist
results.creator_credit: Harry Webb and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description: An artist explains how he sees the framework of a painting, how he develops the angles and how he envisages the end result. Shows examples of his work.

results.title: Extraordinary American films produced between 1899-1908
results.brief_description:
Compilation of silent motion pictures restored from the Library of Congress paper prints.
Contents: Love and war (prod: James H. White, 1899)—The Girl from Montana (prod: William N. Selig, 1907)—His first ride (prod: William N. Selig, 1907)—The Bandit ring (prod: William N. Selig, 1907)—The Bank robbery (prod: Oklahoma Natural Mutoscene Company, 1908)

results.title: Extinction is forever!
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer and Victoria. Ministry of Education
results.brief_description: Kerry Aulsbrook, an Education Officer specializing in natural history at the Museum of Victoria introduces Australian customs regulations prohibiting imports of animals and natural products. Examines the threats faced by species now close to extinction because of human interference.
